Topic: Draw animals in their habitats with labels (e.g., fish in water).
CAN: The student can draw basic representations of a few different animals and plants (e.g., fish, tree, bird).
The student can label some places where animals and plants live but may use general terms (e.g., 'water' for fish without specifying 'ocean' or 'lake').
The student can show a basic relationship between animals and their habitat (e.g., fish in water) with partial success.
CANNOT: The student may label habitats incorrectly or inconsistently (e.g., placing a deer in water).
The student may not accurately show what plants and animals need to survive (e.g., not including air or mislabeling sunlight).
The student struggles to illustrate how resources in the habitats meet the needs of the plants and animals (e.g., may not show land resources at all).
The student may not clearly illustrate or label the systemic relationship between environments and living things (student thinks animals only need food, without considering habitat resources).
